definition.en: an intrusion along a decollement zone, with or without tonguelike extensions into the surrounding rock
a body of igneous rock formed by the process of emplacement of magma in pre-existing rock
a gas cavity or vesicle in an igneous rock which is filled with secondary minerals
a rock derived from igneous processes at or just below the Earth's surface
an offshoot from a larger intrusive body
a discordant magma body with exposed surface area of more than 100 square kilometres; typically consists of multiple intrusions.
a fragment or clast in a rock composed of the remains of organisms
a fragment of pre-existing rocks which have been produced by the processes of weathering and/or erosion, and in general transported to a point of deposition.
an angular pyroclast > 64 mm
a particle ejected during a volcanic eruption
a clot of lava, usually mafic-ultramafic, ejected from a volcanic vent while viscous, and which assumes a rounded shape as it solidifies in flight
an obscurely cactus-shaped intrusion.
an intrusion so irregular as to defy description
a hard, compact mass or aggregate of mineral matter, normally subsperical but commonly oblate, disc-shaped or irregular.  Formed from precipitation from solution about a nucleus or centre
an arcuate dyke that dips 30-45 degrees towards the centre of the arc; occur in concentric sets, presumably converging at a magmatic centre
an association of ring dykes and cone sheets.
a cooling unit in a volcanic rock defined by polygonal jointing perpendicular to the flow surface
a volcanic body of rock formed by subsurface explosive activity
a crystal formed during accumulation of early-formed crystals from a magma
a homogeneous, solid body of a mineral or element having a regular repeating atomic arrangement
a large upward projection of the roof of an igneous intrusion into the country rock above.
a concordant intrusion, teardrop-shaped in cross section
a tabular igneous intrusion that cuts across the bedding or foliation of the country rock
a set of dykes, generally subparallel, with a common origin
an inclusion within an igneous rock to which it may or may not be genetically related
a fragment of older material within an igneous rock to which it may or may not be genetically related
a discordant, funnel-shaped intrusion, tapers downward
an extrusion forming a bulbous dome above and around a volcanic vent
a lateral variant of a lithostratigraphic or metamorphic unit
a volcanic conduit having the form of a crack or fissure.
a upward projection of country rock into an igneous intrusion
an aggregate of crystals of the same mineral
a compositional band or layer in a gneiss mineralogically distinct from the surrounding material
a thin layer, compositionally distinct from the surrounding material
a regular poikilitic intergrowth of triangular or linear-angular shaped grains of one mineral within a larger other mineral, typically quartz with alkali feldspar
a phacolith with a vertical axis; indicates multiple deformations
a concordant, lenticular intrusion, emplaced along a fold axis
a pluton emplaced at a high or subvolcanic level in the crust
a crystalloblast that is newly and completely formed during metamorphism
a crystal of a mineral produced entirely by metamorphic processes
a rock or mineral derived from hydrothermal alteration of a rock
a crystalloblast that is formed during metamorphism and is bounded in part by its characteristic crystal faces
a crystalloblast that is formed during metamorphism and is bounded by its characteristic crystal faces
a compositional band or layer in an igneous rock mineralogically distict from the surrounding material
a clast or fragment in a sedimentary rock of another penecontemporaneous sedimentary rock that has been eroded within the basin of deposition
a vein with no obvious form.
an epigenetic mineral filling of a fault or fracture in a host rock, in tabular or sheetlike form, often with associated host rock replacement.
a concordant, flat-based, convex-up intrusion
a discontinuous layer or bed within a sedimentary rock
the light coloured part of a migmatite or other rock with compositional segregations, usually rich in quartz and feldspar
a large, concordant, typically layered igneous intrusion whose floor is convex-down and whose roof may be convex-down or flat.
a laterally continuous stratigraphic marker within another unit.
a layer of sedimentary material bounded above and below by more or less well-defined bedding surfaces
the dark coloured part of a migmatite or other rock with compositional segregations, rich in mafic minerals
a microscopic crystal that polarises light and has some determinable optical properties

A small rounded mass of a mineral or mineral aggregate, usually with a contrasting composition from the enclosing sediment or rock matrix in which it is embedded. A fragment of a coarse grained igneous rock occurring within a finer grained rock.
the enclosing crystal in a poikolitic texture
a variously shaped, concentrically laminated, calcareous sedimentary structure, usually less than 10 cm in diameter, formed by the accretion of successive layered masses of blue-green algae
a mineral or rock particle, generally lacking crystal faces, commonly in relation to sedimentary rocks
a small round or ovate accretionary particle in an oolitic rock, formed of concentric carbonate layers around a nucleus in shallow, wave-agitated water
a small, usually rounded aggregate of clay-sized calcareous (micritic) material, devoid of internal structure, and contained within a well sorted carbonate rock
a relatively large, conspicuous crystal in a porphyrytic igneous rock
a pillow-like lava body extruded beneath water
a tabular extrusive igneous body.
a vertical conduit through the Earth's crust below a volcano, through which magmatic materials have passed; usually filled with volcanic breccia and fragments of older rock.
a small round or ovate accretionary particle, larger and less regular than an ooid, formed by concentric precipitation around a nucleus typically of carbonate (limestone) or iron oxides (laterite)
a vein with length and width significantly greater than its thickness, giving the vein a tabular form.
a roughly cylindrical mass of congealed magma that fills the conduit of an inactive volcano
a deep-seated igneous intrusion
an intrusion of elongate or lenticular form
a crystal formed by recrystallisation during metamorphism with numerous inclusions of smaller grains
a pseudoporphyritic crystal in a rock produced by metamorphic recrystallisation
a paleoblast within a finer grained recrystalllised and/or pulverised matrix
a secondary mineral whose outward crystal form has been inherited from the orignal mineral it has replaced
a peripheral zone around a mineral composed of the products of the reaction of an early solidified mineral with a surrounding melt
a zone of minerals, commonly with radial arrangement, around another mineral
an arcuate or subcircular dyke, generally associated with a volcanic centre.
a downward projection of country rock into an igneous intrusion
a tabular sedimentary intrusion that cuts across the bedding or foliation of the host rock
a tabular intrusion, concordant or slightly discordant.
a vein is curved so as to resemble the letter S in section.
a tabular igneous intrusion that parallels the bedding or foliation of the country rock.
a wedge-like intrusion, partly concordant, partly discordant.
a rounded or spherical mass of acicular crystals, commonly of feldspar radiating from a central point.  Commonly formed from devitrification of volcanic glass
a discordant magma body with exposed surface area of less than 100 square kilometres; may represent exposed portion of a much larger intrusion.
an intimate wormlike or irregular intergrowth of two different minerals
mode of occurrence is unknown
a secondary mineral or material derived from weathering of a rock
a mineral that has grown during metamorphism without development of its characteristic crystal faces
a crystal that resembles a phenocryst in an igneous rock, but that is foreign to the rock in which it occurs
a foreign inclusion in an igneous rock; a fragment of an earlier-formed part of the igneous rock that has a different composition from that of the host rock
chemically precipitated material occuring in the space between grains or clasts of a sedimentary rock
the finer grained material that occurs between coarser grains or particles in a rock
growth of one mineral around the margin of a pre-existing mineral grain
sedimentary material derived from the waethering and/or erosion
the finer grained material between the phenocrysts of a porphyritic igneous rock
the finer grained material between the larger grains or clasts of a sedimentary rock
